thread.title: Military contractor admits bribes, kickbacks for work at N.J. bases
thread.title_full: Military contractor admits bribes, kickbacks for work at N.J. bases

author: Thomas Moriarty | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Military contractor admits bribes, kickbacks for work at N.J. bases
text:
comments 
NEWARK -- A former construction contractor for U.S. military facilities in New Jersey admitted Tuesday to paying more than $90,000 in bribes to an Army employee to secure subcontracts at two bases. 
George Grassie, of Covington Township, Pa., pleaded guilty before U.S. District Judge Susan D. Wigenton in Newark to charges of conspiring to defraud the United States and commit bribery, and providing unlawful kickbacks, according to a statement from the office of U.S. Attorney Paul Fishman. 
Grassie, 54, was a subcontractor for construction, excavation and landscaping work at Picatinny Arsenal in Wharton and at Joint Base McGuire-Dix Lakehurst, according to prosecutors. 
N.J. cops' 2-year military surplus haul: $40M in gear, 13 armored vehicles 
Grassie admitted paying bribes valued at between $95,000 and $150,000 to an employee of the U.S. Army Contracting Command in New Jersey from December 2010 to December 2013 to obtain and retain subcontracts for work at the two bases. 
He also admitted paying kickbacks valued at $40,000 to $95,000 to two managers of a prime contractor at the bases. 
Those managers, Shawn Fuller and James Conway , have already pleaded guilty in the case, authorities said. 
Grassie faces up to 10 years in prison for the kickbacks, and up to five years in prison on the conspiracy charge, according to the U.S. Attorney's Office. His sentencing has been scheduled for May 31.
